# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

```julia
using AbstractString, Unicode

function wrap_string(text::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text, ASCIIOnly))
    wrapped_text = ""

    for word in words
        wrapped_text *= "$word\n"
        if length(wrapped_text) > text_width
            wrapped_text = wrapped_text[end:text_width] + "\n...\n" # Add ellipses for the truncated part
        end
    end

    return wrapped_text
end

# Example usage
text = "This is a sample text with multiple words. Let's see how it wraps when the text width exceeds 10 characters."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text)
println(wrapped_text)
```

In this example, I've implemented a `wrap_string` function that takes a string and a maximum text width as inputs. The function splits the input text into words, and then iterates over the words to wrap them with new lines when necessary.

The provided example uses a sample text and demonstrates how the wrapped text looks when the text width exceeds 10 characters.
